Tabs

Tabs are elements that help you organize and navigate multiple documents in a single container. They can be used for switching between items in the container.

Basic HTML

You can create tabs with this basic directive

Tab content 1
Tab content 2

Advanced HTML

You can create advanced versions of tabs with these additional directive options

Tab content 1
Tab content 2
Tab content 3
Tab content 1
Tab content 2
Tab content 3
  • auto-open: By default, the tabs will auto open the first tab in the container. Set the auto-open attribute to false to change this functionality.
  • collapsible: By default, one tab must be open at all times. Set the collapsible attribute to true to change this functionality. This will enable toggling the tabs.

External Triggers

The tabs can be opened and closed outside the tabs component using the ba-open, ba-close, and ba-toggle directives.

Relocate Content

By default, the content for ba-tabs is placed directly below the tabs header. This can be changed by using the displaced attribute on the tabs which allows easy positioning of the tab content using ba-tab-content. The target for the ba-tab-content must match the desired ba-tabs id.

The code above works great so long as ba-tab-content is rendered after ba-tabs. Attempting to render ba-tab-content before ba-tabs will break the communication between the two components. In order to resolve this issue, use ng-if and ng-init as shown below to ensure the components are rendered in the correct order.

Accessing Parent Data

The tabs directive uses an isolated scope, meaning data from the parent scope cannot be accessed directly. In order to access properties on the parent scope, one must use $parent. For more information on angular scopes, check the angular docs. The example below shows how to access data from a parent scope using ba-tabs.

{{ $parent.message }}
{{ $parent.clicks }}
Click Me Reset
{{ $parent.data.clicks2 }}
Click Me Reset
{{ $parent.message }}
{{ $parent.clicks }}
Click Me Reset
{{ $parent.data.clicks2 }}
Click Me Reset

Take special look at the differences between the two click examples. The first example uses functions on the parent scope to modify the value, while the second example modifies the value directly. The second example does not work if you attempt to modify the $parent.clicks value instead of the $parent.data.clicks2 value. The reason has to due with how angular binds to data. Using a primitive value on the scope causes the binding to break in the second example. This is fixed by storing the value in an object and assigning the object to the scope. This makes angular bind to the object instead of the primitive value, allow the value to be manipulated by child scopes without breaking any bindings.

Controller used in example above:

function TabsController($scope) { $scope.message = "Hello World!"; $scope.clicks = 0; $scope.data = { clicks2: 0 }; $scope.doClick = function() { $scope.clicks++; }; $scope.reset = function() { $scope.clicks = 0; }; }

Sass Mixins

Use our mixins to write your own tab classes.

// This is the container for your tabstrip .custom-tabs { @include tabstrip( $orientation: horizontal, // Can also be vertical $background: #fff ); } // This is an individual tab .custom-tabs-item { @include tabstrip-item( $background: #fff, // Background color $background-hover: #fff, // Background color on hover $background-active: #fff, // Background color when active $color: #000, // Text color $color-active: #000, // Text color when active $padding: 1rem ); } // This is the container for tab content panes .custom-tab-content { @include tab-content( $padding: 1rem ); } // This is an individual tab pane .custom-tab-content-item { @include tab-content-item; }
